Plays > The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

– Click image to view.

The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

(本朝廿四孝) (Honchō nijūshikō)

Written By: Chikamatsu Hanji (近松半二) , Miyoshi Shōraku (三好松洛) , Takeda Inaba (竹田因幡) , Takeda Koide (竹田小出) , Takeda Heishichi (竹田平七) , Takemoto Saburobei (竹本三郎兵衛)

First Staged: 1766

Reference: Keene, Donald, Bunraku: The Art of the Japanese Puppet Theatre (Tokyo: Kodansha International, 1973); Kokuritsu Gekijō jōen shiryōshū, edited by Kokuritsu Gekijō Geinō Chōsashitsu, vol. 221, December 1983; Bunraku December 1983 Performance Program; Hironaga, Shūzaburō, The Bunraku Handbook (Tokyo: Maison des Arts, 1976)

Kashira:

Fukeoyama (老女形)

Kuchiaki Bunshichi (口あき文七)

Bunshichi (文七)

Yokanbei (与勘平)

Kōmei (孔明)

Kenbishi (検非違使)

Sadanoshin (定之進)

Musume (娘)

Ōshūto (大舅)

Kiichi (鬼一)

Hanaugoki (鼻動き)

Toraō (虎王)

Hagataki (端敵)

Yashio (八汐)

Baba (jidai) (婆（時代）)

Koyaku (子役)

Genta (源太)

Wakaotoko (若男)

Sanmaime (三枚目)

Oniwaka (鬼若)

Darasuke (陀羅助)

Kodanshichi (小団七)

Otoko koyaku (男子役)

Kintoki (金時)

Hayaku (端役)

Genta (nemuri tsuki) (源太眠りつき)

Shūto (舅)

Nemuri no musume (ねむりの娘)

Baba (婆)

Performances:

October 1969: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

July 1973: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

October 1975: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

December 1975: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

January 1977: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

August 1978: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

January 1981: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

April 1983: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

December 1983: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

April 1988: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

May 1988: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

February 1997 Kioi Hall: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

September 1992: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

January 1993: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

January 1998: The Twenty-Four Dutiful Sons

Scenes:

The Honnoji Temple (本能寺)

Lady Ano's Reports to Hisayoshi (局注進)

Chozaemon's Suicide (長左衛門切腹)

The Myoshinji Temple (妙心寺)

The Fort of Suginomori (杉の森)

The Melons Offered to Hisayoshi (瓜献上)

The Daianji River Bank (大安寺堤)

Street Entertainers (万歳)

The Fisherwoman (海女)

The Gourd Trellis (夕顔棚)

Komachi in Her Old Age (関寺小町)

The Amagasaki Village (尼が崎)

Heron Girl (鷺娘)

The Zama Shrine (座摩社前)

Kokaji the Swordsmith (小鍛冶)

The Oil Store (油屋)

The Village of Nozaki (野崎村)

Nagamachi Street (長町)

Characters:

Nureginu (腰元濡衣)

Lady Tokiwai (奥方常盤井)

Yoshikiyo Murakami (村上義清)

Blind Katsuyori (盲勝頼)

Hyobu Itagaki (板垣兵部)

Minosaku, in fact Takeda Katsuyori (簑作実は武田勝頼)

Shingen Takeda (武田信玄)

Kakusuke, a servant (奴角助)

Hakibeii (Hakubei), a servant (奴掃兵衛)

Sekibei, in fact Dosan (花守関兵衛実は斎藤道三)

Kenshin Nagao (長尾謙信)

Kagekatsu Nagao (長尾景勝)

Yaegaki (八重垣姫)

Rokuro (白須賀六郎)

Kobunji (原小文治)

Kansuke (山本勘助)

Yoshiharu, the Shogun (将軍義晴)

Lady Taoyame, Shogun's wife (手弱女御前)

Ujitoki Hojo (北条氏時)

Yamashironosuke (直江山城之助)

Yatsuhashi (腰元八つ橋)

Shizunokata, Shogun's mistress (愛妾賤の方)

Shinzaemon Inoue, in fact Dosan Saito (井上新左衛門 実は 斉藤道三)

Heinai Yokota (横田兵内)

Toma Ochiai (落合藤馬)

Karaori, Kosaka (Takasaka)'s wife (高坂妻唐織)

Irie, Koshina's wife (越名妻入江)

Jihizo, in fact Yamashironosuke (慈悲蔵 実は 直江山城之助)

Danjo Tokitsuna Kosaka (高坂弾正)

Danjo Tadamasa Koshina (越名弾正)

Otane, in fact Yatsuhashi (お種 実は 腰元八つ橋)

Kansuke's widow (Kansuke II's mother, Koshiji) (勘助の母 (母越路))

Yokozo, Kansuke Yamamoto II (横蔵 後に 山本勘助)

Minematsu (伜峰松)

Shogoro, a farmer (百姓正五郎)

Tosuke, a farmer (百姓戸助)

Gunta Iiyama (飯山軍太)

Gonroku, a carter (車遣い権六)

Kampachi, a carter (車遣い勘八)

Kusuke, a rogue (車遣い九介(助))

Dosan Saito (斎藤道三)

Servants (奴)

Jirokichi (次郎吉)

Maid servants (腰元)

Soldiers (雑兵)
